channel.title: Simple Chemistry Question - CarbonMonoxide
channel.description: So there I was revising chemistry for up coming exams, it seemed that i forgot all the basics. I started with covalent bonding, it's simple and all but when i start thinking about CO (Carbon Monoxide). How does the oxygen bond with the carbon? C6 and O8... Wikipedia said it was a triple bond, that doesnt satisfy either the carbon or the oxygen molecule. How does this work? :confused: Thanks for reading. :D

item.title: Simple Chemistry Question - CarbonMonoxide
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

[quote=“xxlegitxx, post:2, topic:168243”]You Brits are so weird. Revising? More like reviewing.

Anyway, I forgot all this also, but here’s my interpretation. It’s a resonance structure, but formal charge dictates that the triple bond C-O is most important. To achieve this, oxygen donates an electron to carbon and they share three electrons. Tada![/quote]

Lol thanks for the help man.

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Chemistry Question - CarbonMonoxide
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

dumbolder:

As far as I know the tripple bond C-O is the only valid Lewis structure, so there is no need for resonance either. (And if you look at the formal charges, it would be the double bond C-O that is optimal, but it’s not a valid structure)

Carbon monoxide does resonate. And the double bond C-O wouldn’t fill carbon’s valence shell, so you can’t even compare.

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Chemistry Question - CarbonMonoxide
item.dc:creator: @dumbolder dumbolder
item.description:
@dumbolder wrote:

xxlegitxx:

Anyway, I forgot all this also, but here’s my interpretation. It’s a resonance structure, but formal charge dictates that the triple bond C-O is most important. To achieve this, oxygen donates an electron to carbon and they share three electrons. Tada!

As far as I know the tripple bond C-O is the only valid Lewis structure, so there is no need for resonance either. (And if you look at the formal charges, it would be the double bond C-O that is optimal, but it’s not a valid structure)

@xxlegitxx wrote:

You Brits are so weird. Revising? More like reviewing.

Anyway, I forgot all this also, but here’s my interpretation. It’s a resonance structure, but formal charge dictates that the triple bond C-O is most important. To achieve this, oxygen donates an electron to carbon and they share three electrons. Tada!
